results.abstract: NASA says that all future American astronauts staying aboard Russian space station Mir will very likely have to be qualified to make space walks, because many will be required to repair and maintain aging craft; new policy means that Comdr Wendy B Lawrence, who has trained for Mir for year, will be replaced by her backup, Dr David A Wolf; photo; Lawrence will fly on shuttle Atlantis when it takes Wolf up to Mir; Lawrence is too short to use bulky Russian spacesuits that must be worn (S)

headline.main: Future Astronauts Must Walk Before They Fly

results.snippet: All future American astronauts staying aboard the Russian space station Mir will very likely have to be qualified to make space walks, a NASA official said today.    The official, Frank Culbertson, NASA's manager of the space shuttle-Mir cooperative...
results.lead_paragraph: All future American astronauts staying aboard the Russian space station Mir will very likely have to be qualified to make space walks, a NASA official said today. The official, Frank Culbertson, NASA's manager of the space shuttle-Mir cooperative research program, said so many space walks will be required to repair and maintain the aging Russian station that American visitors should be prepared to back up Russian crews doing most of the work.

results.abstract: Mission to repair the trouble-plagued space station Mir is crucial to Russian space program; success will demonstrate that Russia is still a vital repository of experience and expertise on space operations; failure will be exploited by growing legions of critics who say that glory days of Russian space program are past and that NASA is endangering its astronauts by training them on Mir; photos; graph shows the tight budget on which Russian space program is run (M)

headline.main: Mir Shadow Falls on Russian Role in Space

results.snippet: Forty years after launching the world's first satellite, Russia is struggling to conquer space on a shoestring.     The establishment that sought to beat the United States in the space race has been forced to contend with plummeting budgets, shaky...
results.lead_paragraph: Forty years after launching the world's first satellite, Russia is struggling to conquer space on a shoestring. The establishment that sought to beat the United States in the space race has been forced to contend with plummeting budgets, shaky political support and a drain on its scientific talent.

results.abstract: Both oxygen generators aboard Russia's calamity-plagued Mir space station have failed, forcing crew to create oxygen using special chemical 'candles'; officials say crew is in no danger and chemical procedure could supply oxygen to last up to two months; craft carrying repair crew is launched and begins orbiting; increasing number of United States officials are questioning American collaboration in program; diagram; photo (M)

headline.main: Principal Oxygen System Fails Aboard Calamity-Plagued Mir

results.snippet: As a giant Soyuz rocket thundered toward the badly damaged Mir space station,  carrying a crew to undertake crucial repairs, the three astronauts aboard Mir struggled tonight with the latest in its seemingly endless string of calamities.    Earlier...
results.lead_paragraph: As a giant Soyuz rocket thundered toward the badly damaged Mir space station, carrying a crew to undertake crucial repairs, the three astronauts aboard Mir struggled tonight with the latest in its seemingly endless string of calamities. Earlier today, Russian space officials disclosed that both oxygen generators aboard the aging spacecraft have failed and that the crew has been forced to create oxygen by lighting special chemical ''candles.''

results.abstract: Maureen Dowd Op-Ed column on Mattel's plans for new, politically correct Barbie dolls, including dentist Barbie (M)
results.snippet: So I think about writing about the Mayor and sex. Then I think, nah.    So I think about writing about the President and sex. Then I think, nah.
results.lead_paragraph: So I think about writing about the Mayor and sex. Then I think, nah. So I think about writing about the President and sex. Then I think, nah.

results.abstract: Space shuttles now face their hardest and most dangerous job: transporting into orbit and assembling components of international space station; experts are split on whether aging spaceships and their astronaut crews are up to the task; critics of program warn that risk of failure is great, with problems worse than those currently being experienced by Russian space station Mir; but officials of National Aeronautics and Space Administration are confident of success; they point to recent flawless launching of shuttle Discovery, and lengthening record of punctuality, which they say bodes well for station job; starting in 1998, shuttles are to spend vast majority of their time on the project; station will be size of football field and, by 2003, will hold up to seven astronauts; photo (M)

headline.main: Spirits Soar As Shuttle Prepares For New Era

results.snippet: After 16 years of flight, more than $68 billion and a stretch of lassitude, the space shuttles are facing their hardest and most dangerous job: transporting into orbit and assembling the components of the international space station.    Experts are...
results.lead_paragraph: After 16 years of flight, more than $68 billion and a stretch of lassitude, the space shuttles are facing their hardest and most dangerous job: transporting into orbit and assembling the components of the international space station. Experts are split on whether the aging spaceships and their astronaut crews are up to the task. For a long time, critics of the program have warned that the risk of failure is great. The problems, they contend, could make the current woes of the Russian space station, Mir, look tame in comparison.

results.abstract: Commander Vasily Tsibliyev and flight engineer Aleksandr Lazutkin of troubled Russian space station Mir return to earth, after longest, most serious and most highly publicized string of disasters in 11-year history of space station; comments by Pres Boris N Yeltsin and Viktor Blagov, deputy flight director at Mission Control, suggest that Vasily Tsibliyev, the commander, will be held accountable; final judgments on crewmen will have to wait until next week, when other astronauts begin to repair damage to Mir when supply ship rammed into side of science module while Tsibliyev was guiding it; photos (M)

headline.main: Hapless Crew Of Mir Station Back on Earth

results.snippet: After six of the least glorious months in the history of manned space flight, the hapless crew of the Mir space station retreated from the cosmos this afternoon, floating to earth three hours later in a cloud of dust on the steppes of Kazakstan.    ...
results.lead_paragraph: After six of the least glorious months in the history of manned space flight, the hapless crew of the Mir space station retreated from the cosmos this afternoon, floating to earth three hours later in a cloud of dust on the steppes of Kazakstan. ''I hope that everything that went wrong here is leaving with us,'' the forlorn commander, Vasily Tsibliyev, told the three crew members who remained, as he prepared to leave the space station. ''We are leaving now. See you on earth.''

results.snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-13    Ill-Fated Astronaut Happy To Be Back From Space  Vasily Tsibliyev said he was happy to be back from the Russian space station Mir after a seemingly relentless series of mishaps during his tenure as commander. But the dusty...
results.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Ill-Fated Astronaut Happy To Be Back From Space Vasily Tsibliyev said he was happy to be back from the Russian space station Mir after a seemingly relentless series of mishaps during his tenure as commander. But the dusty steppes of Kazakhstan, where his Soyuz capsule landed, promised to be more hospitable than Moscow, where President Boris Yeltsin proclaimed human error to be the cause of the troubles which plagued the technically sophisticated Mir. A1 Pakistan, Too, Turns 50 Pakistanis were hardly sanguine as they celebrated the 50th anniversary of their country's independence. At least 70 people have been killed in clashes between rival Muslim sects in recent days, appearing to many as a troubling allegory of the nation's violent history, much of which has been spent under military rule. A1

results.abstract: Profile of portrait painter Everett Raymond Kinstler of Easton, Conn, who has painted several portraits of Pres Bill Clinton; photo (M)
results.snippet: IN Easton, if President Bill Clinton looms large, it's because the portrait artist Everett Raymond Kinstler is making him that way.     His painting of the President -- which measures 50 inches by 60 inches -- was commissioned by the Yale Club of New...
results.lead_paragraph: IN Easton, if President Bill Clinton looms large, it's because the portrait artist Everett Raymond Kinstler is making him that way. His painting of the President -- which measures 50 inches by 60 inches -- was commissioned by the Yale Club of New York and in November will join his portraits of Presidents Gerald Ford and George Bush, which already hang in the club's main lounge. Four United States presidents (including William Howard Taft, whose portrait was painted by Augustus Vincent Tack) had connections to Yale University.

results.abstract: Main computer aboard Russian Mir space station fails, sending spacecraft spinning out of control during docking with cargo ship; forces new crew to shut down all major power systems after docking and to temporarily abandon Mir for Soyuz space capsule, using its engines to push wobbling station back toward orbit; Russian space officials voice dismay; are unable to explain cause of accident, latest in longest string of serious mishaps in space history; say crew is in no immediate danger; accident will postpone repairs on station's Spektr module, which was damaged during docking with supply ship on June 15; recent computer failure, following accidental disconnection of power cable by crew, recalled; photo (M)

headline.main: Computer Breakdown on the Mir Sends It Spinning Out of Control

results.snippet: Fortune's relentless assault on the space station Mir continued today, when the craft's main computer failed and sent it spinning out of control as it was docking with a cargo ship.    Somehow the Mir's new commander, Anatoly Solovyov, managed to...
results.lead_paragraph: Fortune's relentless assault on the space station Mir continued today, when the craft's main computer failed and sent it spinning out of control as it was docking with a cargo ship. Somehow the Mir's new commander, Anatoly Solovyov, managed to steer the Progress supply craft into its berth before the station lost its bearings. But the crew was then forced to shut down all major power systems and abandon the Mir for the Soyuz space capsule so they could use its engines to push the wobbling station back toward its orbit.

results.abstract: Fresh crew aboard Mir space station carry out riskiest and most essential repairs in station's long and troubled history; restore electrical cables, cut in collision with supply ship on June 25, in six-hour mission that involved space walk; were slightly delayed by leaky hatch and glove; diagram (M)

headline.main: With Usual Drama, Mir Crew Makes Risky Repair

results.snippet: There were some tense moments in outer space today, but for once the crew of the Mir banished all doubt, carrying out the riskiest and most essential repairs in the Russian space station's long and troubled history.    With the future of the...
results.lead_paragraph: There were some tense moments in outer space today, but for once the crew of the Mir banished all doubt, carrying out the riskiest and most essential repairs in the Russian space station's long and troubled history. With the future of the country's space program dependent on the results, the six-hour mission -- to restore electrical cables cut off after a supply ship crashed into the station on June 25 -- began with trouble. First a leak in one of the compartments forced nearly an hour delay. Then the left glove of one of the astronauts came loose, nearly causing Mission Control to cancel the repairs completely.

results.snippet: ''Pay attention. This is very serious.''    VLADIMIR SOLOVYOV, the Mir flight director, to an astronaut making repairs in space. $(1$)
results.lead_paragraph: ''Pay attention. This is very serious.'' VLADIMIR SOLOVYOV, the Mir flight director, to an astronaut making repairs in space. $(1$)

results.abstract: Main systems for producing oxygen aboard Mir space station break down, presenting three-man crew with fresh setback; NASA says mishap is serious but crew still has enough oxygen to last several days and will try to make repairs; failure to restore flow of oxygen could force crew to return to Earth, dealing humiliating blow to impoverished Russian space program (M)

headline.main: Serious New Setback for Mir: Oxygen Sources Break Down

results.snippet: The two main systems for producing oxygen on the Mir broke down today, presenting its three-man crew with a fresh setback just days after the crippled space station appeared to be on the road to recovery.    NASA described the mishap as ''serious''...
results.lead_paragraph: The two main systems for producing oxygen on the Mir broke down today, presenting its three-man crew with a fresh setback just days after the crippled space station appeared to be on the road to recovery. NASA described the mishap as ''serious'' but said the crew still had enough oxygen to last several days, during which they would try to repair the systems. But failure to restore the flow of oxygen could force the evacuation of the space station and deal a humiliating blow to the impoverished Russian space program.

results.abstract: NASA and Texas officials reveal new computer program that will allow astronauts to cast votes via E-mail, using onboard laptops; development is solution to problem that arose in 1996, when John E Blaha, astronaut and registered voter in Texas, was unable to vote while on four-month mission aboard Mir space station; photo (M)

headline.main: Giant Leap for the Space Crowd: Voting

results.snippet: Among the electoral blocs a politician has to worry about, voters stuck in outer space do not make for a very big constituency -- not yet, anyway. But if and when they do, they will add vast new complexities to the concept of a get-out-the-vote...
results.lead_paragraph: Among the electoral blocs a politician has to worry about, voters stuck in outer space do not make for a very big constituency -- not yet, anyway. But if and when they do, they will add vast new complexities to the concept of a get-out-the-vote drive. Space travelers can now cast ballots in elections back home, NASA and Texas election officials announced today, as they revealed their high-technology solution to what they called one of the more vexing legal and logistical challenges in the history of suffrage.

results.abstract: NASA aides say Russian astronauts had already fixed problem in Mir space station's oxygen-generating system by time NASA issued alarming report of breakdown; say NASA team did not know of repair because it left Russian Mission Control Center before last communication of day with Mir, confident that crew was in no danger (M)

headline.main: NASA's Face Red As Report of Fault On Mir Is Clarified

results.snippet: When NASA said on Monday that Mir's two main oxygen-generating systems had broken down it seemed as if the Russian space station had suffered another humiliating setback.     But the glitch was not so much in space as on the ground. And the problem...
results.lead_paragraph: When NASA said on Monday that Mir's two main oxygen-generating systems had broken down it seemed as if the Russian space station had suffered another humiliating setback. But the glitch was not so much in space as on the ground. And the problem was not with the Russians, but with the Americans.

results.abstract: Editorial holds recent mishaps on Russia's Mir space station are dwarfed by benefits station has yielded for Russia and United States; holds NASA and Russian space agency are right to keep station operating for now (M)
results.snippet: Judging from the jokes and editorial cartoons, the Russian space station Mir is seen as a kind of cosmic scrap heap, with leaks, blackouts, fires and one cliff-hanging repair job after another. But while prominent in the public eye, the mishaps this...
results.lead_paragraph: Judging from the jokes and editorial cartoons, the Russian space station Mir is seen as a kind of cosmic scrap heap, with leaks, blackouts, fires and one cliff-hanging repair job after another. But while prominent in the public eye, the mishaps this year are dwarfed by the benefits the station has yielded both for Russia and its partner in the effort, the United States. When the Russians shut down the station -- as they probably will within a year or so -- they will leave knowing that Mir has substantially advanced what we know about life and work in space and has paved the way for a trip to the nearest planets. Mir has been aloft for 11 years, but it registered in the popular consciousness only in June, when a robot supply ship collided with the station's science laboratory. The collision punctured and depressurized the laboratory compartment, forcing the crew to cut power cables that had been jury-rigged and strung through an open door that now had to be closed. The accident left Mir with only partial power and its science lab out of commission.
